data.title: Give a name to a Terminal session
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

It would be awesome to be able to give a name to a Terminal session. I oftenly have 5 or 6 Terminals opened.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5808108/28663801-b02a31d4-72be-11e7-819c-63b7c4e6e15c.png)

data.title: Inspector loaded scripts: Hide <eval> for scripts from the debug adapter
data.body:
Refs: #31327

1. Debug a node app (for instance our smoke test repo)
2. Open the loaded scripts view
3. Notice the <eval> folder

Those scripts always seem useless to me and do not provide any real value.
Is it common practice to also show these scripts or should we hide them?

Since it is a tree, the user can always just collapse them so maybe showing them is a better choice then implicitly hidding. Though still creating this as a question.

data.title: Window title only repainting when window is resized

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Bookmarks|ale|0.15.2
cucumberautocomplete|ale|2.3.1
vscode-eclipse-keybindings|alp|0.9.6
xml|Dot|1.9.2
LogFileHighlighter|emi|1.1.1
tortoise-svn|fan|0.1.1
vscode-javac|geo|0.0.46
wordcount|ms-|0.1.0
seti-icons|qin|0.1.3
java|red|0.7.0
vscode-icons|rob|7.11.0
velocity|sod|0.1.0

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file with vscode - its name is not placed into the window title
2. Resize the vscode window by either dragging one of the application borders or double-clicking the window title
3. Window title will update

This also applies to tabs - changing tab does not repaint the window title, only a resize will. I had previously changed my `window.title` setting but since removed it from my settings.json and since I've been seeing this problem I'd even explicitly put the default `window.title` setting into settings.json, but it didn't make any difference.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Open loaded scripts from quick open and viewlet show different content
data.body:
Refs: #31327

1. Put a breakpoints somewhere in vsocde unit tests
2. Start debugging our unit tests (they use legacy protocol)
3. Open the loaded scripts view, vscode/amdefine/amdefine.js -> notice how the content is nicely shown

Now open F1 > loaded scripts > find amdefine.js (notice 2 copies, both of them give "Content could not be retrieved"

data.title: Loaded scripts shows empty tree node
data.body: testing #31107 * debugging an extensions * looking the tree and see an empty node (representing the root folder on my machine I believe)

data.title: Debugging 2 extensions doesn't work
data.body:
testing #31107

* generate two hello world extensions (foodoo, bardoo)
* have a multi-root workspace with the extension folders
* in both `extension.ts` files set a break point
* select one launch config, start, happy
* select the other launch config, start, nothing

data.title: Allow to auto resize a custom view or take initial size as input from custom view contributions.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
#31327

Start node debugging, hit a brekapoint, notice the loaded scripts view is very small. Expand an element in the loaded scripts -> you do not see anything.
Optimally the loaded scripts view should also resize a bit in this case.

An alternative is that loaded scripts by default has a bit more space

data.title: Polish - target rendering of the folder in the debug drop down
data.body:
Testing #31396

Currently the folder of a target is shown in parenthesis which looks noisy:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172399/28662889-f561ee2a-72bb-11e7-849e-f6432530cbe1.png)

Suggestions:
- dim the folder and show it in a darker grey so that no parenthesis is needed
- replace the parenthesis with a '-',  Attach - tslint-server

data.title: Too subtle progress while pre-launch task is running
data.body:
I keep starting multiple debug sessions (of the same type) because don't see anything happening after clicking. What actually happens is that a pre-launch task is running and that is very easy to miss. I'd suggest to immediately show the view progress bar (as does later for a short time)

![jul-27-2017 11-10-43](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1794099/28663018-6e958716-72bc-11e7-99c8-84d20c5e175f.gif)

data.title: Quick pick snippet choices: use groups
data.body:
Refs: #31324

F1 > insert snippet 

Notice that all the snippet choices are shown together. It would be nice if you used quick open groups to distinguish between user and regular snippets.
Apart from that I would first show the user group and only then the regular snippets

Here's an example how quick open nicely uses groups to distinguish

![screen shot 2017-07-27 at 11 07 09](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926584/28662839-c8b0dee0-72bb-11e7-97ca-5d6751ab63c1.png)

data.title: "Configure Default Build Task" (Typescript) does not work as expected
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro 1703 15063.483

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install typescript:
`npm install typescript --save-dev`.

2. Create `tsconfig.json ` in the project's root directory:
```
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "es5",
        "module": "commonjs",
        "sourceMap": true,
        "outDir": "./bld",
        "rootDir": "./",
        "strict": true,
        "alwaysStrict": true,
        "moduleResolution": "node"
    }
}
```
3. Create `tasks.json` in `./.vscode`:
```
{
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "type": "typescript",
            "tsconfig": "tsconfig.json",
            "presentation": {
                "echo": true,
                "reveal": "never",
                "focus": false,
                "panel": "shared"
            },
            "group": {
                "kind": "build",
                "isDefault": true
            }
        }
    ]
}
```
4. Create `test.ts` in the project's root directory:
`console.log("Hello, world!");`

5. Open `test.ts` in VS Code editor tab. Press `Ctrl+Shift+B`. Despite isDefault is set to true and 'tsconfig.json' is explicitly specified in `tasks.json`, VS Code still asks to choose default build task: `tsc: build tsconfig.json recently used tasks`. When I press `Ctrl+Shift+B` in the context of other editor tabs, e. g. `tsconfig.json`,  confirmation is not required.

npm tasks work as expected, i. e. I get no additional confirmations if `isDefault: true`.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Adding a configuration from the drop down should not change the target
data.body:
Testing Refs: #31396

In this multi root setup
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172399/28662697-51c33e22-72bb-11e7-845b-7556c910b21c.png)

Notice that I have 'Launch' selected as the target

Add a launch configuration to the server folder
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172399/28662733-75c8e812-72bb-11e7-86be-3df0c1d0b1cb.png)

Now the launch target has changed to 'Attach'
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172399/28662751-8c50caa0-72bb-11e7-94b0-1619e402f250.png)

I should stay on 'Launch'

data.title: Files.associations setting overrides user choice
data.body:
Testing #31448 on Ubuntu Linux 16.04

1. Create `file.foo` and open it
2. Using the status bar, change its mode to CSS
3. Without closing `file.foo`, open settings and add `"files.associations": { "*.foo": "javascript" }`
4. Switch back to `file.foo`

The mode will have been changed to JavaScript, although it should really be CSS since that's what I picked. IMO `files.associations` should only affect the choice of a mode when a file is about to open, not when it is already open, much less when I have explicitly chosen a mode.

data.title: Fix publish.ts script
data.body: It fails to work properly for `darwin-unsigned` and the outcome depends on whether a build from another platform is already there. Check build `6328bae2bf8382fd4abd054c14976548eaea66cf`

data.title: Custom snippet file should have a schema
data.body:
Refs: #31324

Currently editing a javascript.json when editing custom snipets for javascript is a bit tricky because there is no schema.
Having a shema would make the user experience nicer and would make it easier to discover fields, defaults values and so on

data.title: Explorer sort order: rename description
data.body:
Refs: #30719

"Controls sorting order of files and directories in the explorer". compared to the current
"Controls the way of sorting files and directories in the explorer."

data.title: Decouple Mooncake CDN from build path
Do not prompt for saving dirty file if opened as diff editor
data.body:
Testing #30721

- Edit a file
- Run the Compare with file on disk action which opens diff editor
- Close the file

Save prompt is shown. Diff editor with the modified file is still open. We show dirty indicator, in Open editors. May be we can show save prompt when all editors with the file are closed.

data.title: Explorer sorting: "modified" rename to "lastModified"
data.body:
Refs: #30719

I prefer `lastModified` to `modified` as it is more explicit and clear. And I do not see the benefit of having a shorter setting value.
